title: Fix issues with bindings and handling extensions
body:
The way the Guice bindings were setup previously, each process only had bindings
for the things it cared about.  This became problematic when adding extension modules
that bound everything that they could possibly need expecting that the processes would
only instantiate what they actually do need.  Guice tries to fail-fast and verifies that all
 bindings exist before it does anything, which is a problem because the extension bind
 some objects that don't necessarily have all of their dependencies bound in all processes.

The fix for this is to build a single Injector with all bindings in it and let each of the
 processes only load the things that they care about.  This also requires the use of
 Module overrides and other such interesting things, which are node done.

 In doing the fix, I also swapped out the way that the DataSegmentPusher/Puller stuff is bound, as well as made the Cassandra stuff fail if its settings are not provided.  This all of a sudden made all of the things require Cassandra's settings, so I migrated the Cassandra deep storage stuff into its own module.

 In doing these changes, I also discovered that some properties weren't properly converting for the ConvertProperties command (specifically, the properties related to data segment loading and pushing), so I fixed that.

title: Query Results Cache
body:
Caching the query result sequence in form of byte[], improving the performance of repeated queries and reducing load on druid broker.

Cache will ignore the queries which intervals beyond current time, as they are bound to have different results later on.

Performance results for the three cases. The queries were generated randomly should be more than 1k queries (as per the stats)
1. No segment-level and query-results caching
2. No query-results caching but with segment-level results caching
3. Both caching turned on.

Case    |   Broker CPU  |    Compute CPU    |    Response Time 
testCache   |    0.78   |    0.48   |    4.28 
testNoCache |    0.53   |    65.30  |    2,296.28 
testNoQueryCache    |    19.10  |    0.79   |    100.99

title: Make some master configuration properties dynamically configurable
body:
This commit adds the ability to change some Master parameters dynamically. Thus, you can enter a web console and change these parameters while the Master is running. These parameters include:
1. millisToWaitBeforeDeleting - time to wait before dropping a segment from a server.
2. mergeBytesLimit - The maximum number of bytes allowed during a segment merge.
3. mergeSegmentsLimit - The maximum number of segments that can be merged together.
4. maxSegmentsToMove - The max number of segments the master moves on each run.

The web console interface is accessible from [serveraddress]/static/dynamicConfigs.html

title: Remove retry logic out of the Remote Task Runner and introduce Task resources

This pull request also introduces task resources; tasks can announce an availability group and also the capacity they require. Finally, the pull request introduces config simplification.

title: Improve runtime of segment distribution algorithm
body:
This commit reduces the time taken to balance segments across a cluster. On 55K segments, it reduces the time taken for one run of the master from 100+ seconds to <1 second.

It includes the following implementation changes:
1. Removes calls to CalcuateInitialCosts() and CalculateNormalizedCosts(). They were both O(n^2) and weren't necessary.
2. Just tracks the best server instead of keeping a priorityQueue in chooseBestServer.
3. Fixes the reservoir segment sampler so that it is actually random.

And the following architectural changes:
1. Makes the segment balancer algorithm follow the strategy pattern.
2. Adds a random segment balancer should we wish to use that.
3. Adds a profiler to test the speed of the balancer.

title: Adding a RabbitMQFirehoseFactory implementation
body:
Pretty self explanatory.

The major things to be aware of:

1) This implementation will not reconnect if the connection to the MQ broker is lost. This is documented in the JavaDoc class documentation.

2) I added a rabbitmq directory to the examples/bin directory. However, it only contains an example realtime.spec configuration file to get a realtime node running with the RabbitMQFirehoseFactory and a simple example query.body file. It doesn't contain a client that actually produces data into the RabbitMQ exchange. I can provide a simple Java program that does this but I wasn't sure where I should put it.

3) There are some configuration options that are missing. We know about this and we may add it later on. Specifically, neither SASL nor SSL is currently supported.

title: Fix path used when storing segments to HDFS
body:
Hi,

as discussed in https://groups.google.com/d/topic/druid-development/IwYHYdNx_no/discussion, I fixed the HDFS path for segments. 

I use another date format for the intervals which does not contain ':' symbols. I also replace ':' characters with '_' in the version string. This should workaround the already known issue with colons in HDFS (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HDFS-13)

I tested this with hadoop-2.0.0-cdh4. The segments are now pushed to HDFS properly and loaded to compute nodes properly.

Thanks for accepting the modification.
-- Jan

title: AWS CloudFormation Template and AMI to learn Druid capabilities
body:
Hello All,

In the past, we used Druid real time data analytics capabilities to build SF parking meter application that we demonstrated in Strata conference.

To help our engineering team understand and leverage Druid, we created a CloudFormation Stack which builds druid infrastructure topology (Master/Broker on one machine, Compute Node on different machine/s). This allowed us to perform substantial data analytics leveraging druid indexing capabilities on S3. 

For more simpler cases, we have also build an AWS AMI image that has all Master, Broker and Compute in one machine. This really simplifies learning and getting started with Druid.

We will love to share the above collateral with Druid's open source community. Also available in pull request is a white paper explaining the CloudFormation stack and associated read me files.

Regards

Harpreet
Skilled Analysts

milestone.title: Druid Release -- Next

title: Enable the broker to select a compute node will the least number of open connections
body: Instead of randomly selecting a compute node that has a given segment, select the compute node with the least number of open connections. This prevents the broker from potentially flooding an overburdened compute node with requests.

milestone.title: 0.4.32 and before
milestone.description: These are issues that were resolved in 0.4.32 and before.

repo.name: druid
repo.description: Apache Druid: a high performance real-time analytics database.

title: Remove references to i0tec.zkClient and replace with Curator
body:
We've had some issues with ZooKeeper state changes after ZK quorum issues.  Our current zookeeper client is an unsupported library that was just thrown out there, we should switch over to Curator instead.

This will get us on a supported code base and also give us access to their body of knowledge when we do run into issues.

This pull request is the full switch over.

title: Indexing service: workers run tasks in their own JVMs and graceful shutdown of tasks
body: This pull request introduces the ForkingTaskRunner, which can run tasks in their own JVMs and output individual task logs. This pull request also introduces the ability to hard and soft shutdown tasks. For realtime tasks, soft shutdown will stop the task after a realtime segment has been published.
